body: I can take a chance to review this, but I'm not an export of k8s, may not fully understand the pros and cons of the implementation.
ping @jerryshao .Could you help reivew it again?
ping @jerryshao .Could you help reivew it?
any progress?
@jerryshao I check all the notifications on this PR, feel free to add comments on uncertainties, will be glad to describe the idea.

@jahstreet sure. Please feel free to add me to any relevant thread. I am fully convinced that this is a great solution for many organizations that deal with high volume data. Many are looking for but don't know what and how to do. I really hope this one gets integrated with Livy. Many thanks again @jahstreet for the contribution!

Hi @JagadeeshNagella , thx for your interest in this project. Sorry for the typo, my e-mail is `jahstreetlove@gmail.com` - edited in the comment above as well.
This PR uses Livy `0.6.0`, but can be rebased to `0.7.0` easily. The reason why I do not do that is because we decided to split the work introduced in this PR to separate smaller PRs for easier reviewing and merging, and the first one is here: #249 .
To try it out you can refer the [Getting Started](https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/tree/sasnouskikh/documentation#getting-started) and [Documentation](https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/blob/sasnouskikh/documentation/DOCUMENTATION.md#local-setup) pages. Feel free to reach me via the corrected e-mail or create an [Issue](https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/issues), will be glad to assist.

Thank you for your response. I will try Livy on K8s and update you status .
Hey @runzhiwang what's the status of this PR? Are you going to merge this in? I'm having issues with dangling threads with a lot of jobs running simultaneously and this fix will be great to have!
@sanchay0 Thanks for your attention. I have completed the code. And It just need more review.
I could not assign myself the relate jira, how can I do it? @mgaido91 @vanzin @jerryshao
@tmnd1991 you can't, JIRAs are assigned when related patches are merged and they are resolved

> @tmnd1991 you can't, JIRAs are assigned when related patches are merged and they are resolved

Then I think [contributing section](https://livy.apache.org/community/) is wrong :)

I changed what you suggested @mgaido91 , thanks for the review.
Tagging @ajbozarth as he asked on Jira :)

> @tmnd1991 A heads up, when you force push updates to commits it makes it difficult to track your changes as you address review (eg. I can't tell which of @mgaido91 comments you've addressed because there's no history to compare to). Since we squash all commits in a PR before merging the quantity of commits in a PR isn't an issue.

Good, I did not know if the squash before merge was a "thing" in Livy repo, I won't do the same mistake again :)

> As for your code, I read through it and I don't see any issues with the current code, but I don't have to time check it out and more thoroughly test it so I will defer to @mgaido91 on final approval for this PR.

üëç

> @mgaido91 I think your mixing up how Spark handles JIRA assignments with Livy's policy. We assign JIRAs once a PR is open for the issue. For some reason though, I can't assign issues to @tmnd1991 in the Livy JIRA at the moment. We had this issue before but I can't remember how we solved it.

Sorry, I saw the same pattern being followed in Livy too in practice so I assumed it was the same. I think the point is that @tmnd1991 has to be added to the contributors in JIRA. I'll do that when resolving the JIRA.
it's a useful feature, with this user can submit local jars to remote spark cluster.

In our case, we use spark magic in jupyter to connect livy to start the Spark cluster in kubernetes. We have started to use this patch in our work. As more and more applications migrate towards the cloud, this patch is definitely very valuable.  hopefully this feature can be merged asapÔºåso that more people can see and use this feature

This change enables `inspect.findsource` and `torch.jit.script`

@jerryshao

Hi @jahstreet !

Thanks a lot for this contribution, I have tried it today and it works like a charm but I have a question regarding completed / failed pods - are those going to stay indefinitely in k8s like they are now
```
a5b0fae4-6788-4d36-b2d9-52fb324a4c70-1588337906004-driver   0/1     Completed   0          
a730adbe-1c6b-472c-8206-822a6987b6a1-1588336487771-driver   0/1     Completed   0          
af3ca255-556c-41a1-8021-bdd0e0d691ae-1588337573608-driver   0/1     Completed   0          
b3c8d0d1-46e5-44e1-883d-94d7df8680cf-1588337480374-driver   0/1     Completed   0          
bb05602c-3a44-4ea7-8d8d-3929f480ea3e-1588337872526-driver   0/1     Completed   0          
bb23af70-25ad-407d-8682-d9d5f5d03861-1588337545733-driver   0/1     Error       0          
```
or livy is supposed to purge completed jobs in a while? 

Thanks in advance!

Hi @plavreshin , you can control how long to keep them with [livy.server.session.state-retain.sec](https://github.com/apache/incubator-livy/pull/167/files#diff-486ae8357b2836f1addaafe102d02287R58) Livy server config. After the configured timeout the pods will be deleted as well as the linked resources (ConfigMaps, Services, Ingresses, etc.). If it is not so, it is a bug =)

> Hi @plavreshin , you can control how long to keep them with [livy.server.session.state-retain.sec](https://github.com/apache/incubator-livy/pull/167/files#diff-486ae8357b2836f1addaafe102d02287R58) Livy server config. After the configured timeout the pods will be deleted as well as the linked resources (ConfigMaps, Services, Ingresses, etc.). If it is not so, it is a bug =)

Thanks for prompt reply @jahstreet , I am using fairly default configuration as proposed in https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/blob/master/charts/livy/values.yaml#L112

and seems that those pods should have been deleted after 12h 
```
  LIVY_LIVY_SERVER_SESSION_STATE0RETAIN_SEC: {value: "12h"}
  LIVY_LIVY_SERVER_SESSION_MAX0CREATION: {value: "10"}
```

so looks like a bug indeed. I will give it a try once more and can create an Issue / provide more details

> and seems that those pods should have been deleted after 12h

Yes, if you haven't restarted Livy Pod or have StateStore configured. If so and Spark Pods haven't been deleted, then after 12h you should've seen an error in the Livy logs.

> I will give it a try once more and can create an Issue / provide more details

Thanks, feel free to post it [here](https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/issues). Then we can look into the issue together.

> I can take a chance to review this, but I'm not an export of k8s, may not fully understand the pros and cons of the implementation.

@jerryshao , have you given it a try already?

Hi @jahstreet this is great, thank you for this. How would you address authorization for this on a Kubernetes cluster? I am looking to secure the REST API from internal traffic to the Kubernetes cluster, say for Jupyter notebooks that run in parallel to Livy. I want it to honor RBAC from other workspaces without the use of network policy
any update on this? is this still planed to be added?

Hi @marcjimz , good question. This PR doesn't cover your use case. For securing access to Livy I would recommend you to look through the existing Livy auth, access control, user impersonation and related features. Unfortunately I haven't seen any good docs on that part yet.
Also with regards to the tradeoffs you are ok to make, you can use auth proxies, Livy-as-a-sidecar per Jupyter or your custom RBAC integrations.

@jahstreet thanks, I ended up adding a servlet filter to the Livy base and was able to achieve the same as fine. I also edited the helm chart to support basic auth which I can commit if of interest.

Hoping this PR gets accepted by the upstream.

> I also edited the helm chart to support basic auth which I can commit if of interest

Definitely yes, any contribution is appreciated. Thank you for sharing your use case.

I am seeing an issue where livy sessions are disappearing after 600 seconds. 

`2020-05-13 23:18:25 ERROR SparkKubernetesApp:52 - Error while refreshing Kubernetes state
java.lang.IllegalStateException: No Kubernetes application is found with tag livy-session-0-Ds53hoGu in 600 seconds. This may be because 1) spark-submit fail to submit application to Kubernetes; or 2) Kubernetes cluster doesn't have enough resources to start the application in time. Please check Livy log and Kubernetes log to know the details.`

However, my pod is not named livy-session-0-Ds53hoGu
Hi @ajbozarth , @jerryshao , any chance this can be included in 0.8?

Hi @marcjimz , can you share more details on the issue, eg. setup you have, Livy configs and the way you submit the session, etc. Saying everything you feel might be related and enough to reproduce the issue. Thanks.

@mgaido91 can you please merge this (since you have already approved it)?
I thought it was already merged, but it appears that it isn't.

Hi, @jahstreet 

I have been using this branch for my project but I am getting weird behaviour with mutable treeSet inside a class.

Below code works on Livy on local deployment and with yarn and spark on local and client mode on kubernetes

`class EnclosingClass() extends Serializable { var treeSet = new scala.collection.mutable.TreeSet[(Long, Long)]() };`

`sc.parallelize(1 to 10).toDF.rdd.map(row => (1, row(0).toString.toLong)).aggregate(new EnclosingClass)(seqOp = (columnStats, value) => {columnStats}, combOp = (c,a) => {println(c.treeSet.size); println(c.treeSet); c })"`

Output
`
-1050225384
Set()
`

Expected Output
`
0
TreeSet()
`

Can you help/guide What could be the cause or where to look for?

Hi @amarjeetkapoor1 , not quite sure I get you point on how it relates to Livy and its Kubernetes setup. Please try to reach me via e-mail jahstreetlove@gmail.com with more details on how do you actually execute this code, will be glad to help.

CI completed and passed. I don't know why the status did not get updated here.
@mgaido91 @jerryshao can you please review?
I am not sure about this change, may you please elaborate more on the previous behavior and why it is problematic? Maybe an example or some screenshots would help clarifying. Thanks.

@mgaido I explained the issue in the description of [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIVY-771](url). I also just called out in comments on the code what the problem is.
To repeat myself, if you have a column in a table of decimal(5, 2) type, e.g., then you should have values that have 2 places after the decimal point. Livy TS is returning values that do not conform to that type. It returns values such as 123.4 instead of 123.40, or 123 instead of 123.00, or 1.2E+2 instead of 120.00.

beeline to HS2:

```
> select f_decimal from hive_types_test order by f_int limit 1;
+------------+
| f_decimal  |
+------------+
| 9.40       |
+------------+
1 row selected (14.31 seconds)
```

beeline to Livy TS:
```
> select f_decimal from hive_types_test order by f_int limit 1;
+------------+
| f_decimal  |
+------------+
| 9.4        |
+------------+
1 row selected (11.544 seconds)
```

spark-shell:
```
scala> val df = spark.sql("select f_decimal from hive_types_test order by f_int")
df: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [f_decimal: decimal(5,2)]

scala> val row = df.first()
row: org.apache.spark.sql.Row = [9.40]                                          

scala> val elem = row.get(0)
elem: Any = 9.40

scala> elem.isInstanceOf[java.math.BigDecimal]
res2: Boolean = true

scala> elem == new java.math.BigDecimal("9.40")
res3: Boolean = true

scala> elem == new java.math.BigDecimal("9.4")
res4: Boolean = false

scala> new java.math.BigDecimal("9.40").stripTrailingZeros() == new java.math.BigDecimal("9.4")
res5: Boolean = true
```

I just did a quick review about the overall implementation. Seems like we can only support one Scala version for one build here  in this PR. But Livy could actually support different versions of Scala in one build (we used to support Scala 2.10 and 2.11 for one build). So I think we should have both Scala 2.12 and 2.11 support, and let Livy to choose jars automatically based on the Spark.
